title: Chelsea team photo featuring Jose Mourinho at Stamford Bridge is removed
title_page: Chelsea team photo featuring Jose Mourinho at Stamford Bridge is removed | Daily Mail Online
text:
Supporters had made it their routine to get in the picture next to Mourinho
Any last remnants of Jose Mourinho's second spell at Chelsea have been removed from the outskirts of Stamford Bridge.
The only reference of the Special One in the surroundings of the stadium had been a large team picture mounted on a wall near the Britannia Gate entrance on Fulham Road. That was until last weekend.
The picture, which included the Portuguese manager alongside Branislav Ivanovic and John Terry with last season's Capital One Cup and Premier League trophies, was removed before Chelsea played Scunthorpe United in the third round of the FA Cup on Sunday.
The 2015-16 team photograph that includes both the Premier League and Capital One Cup trophies
Team picture of the squad that began the 2014-15 season for Chelsea managed by Jose Mourinho
Chelsea fans had made it their routine to get a picture stood next to Mourinho and Chelsea's John Terry
The image in its place now is an adidas and Delta sponsors montage with the slogans: 'If it's not blue, it will not do. #bethedifference' and 'Keeping the blue flag flying high'.
Mourinho was sacked as Chelsea manager on December 17 after a poor run of performances including nine defeats in 16 games and ill feeling in the dressing room left owner Roman Abramovich with no choice but to relieve the 52-year-old of his duties.
Mourinho's second spell at Stamford Bridge reaped the club their fourth Premier League title and a fifth League Cup.
His defence of the Premier League crown was going disastrously before he was sacked, which further added fuel to the argument that the Portuguese manager finds it difficult to maintain momentum when his time with a club goes to a third season.
Guus Hiddink was appointed as Chelsea's new manager on December 19 and has attempted to guide the team back on to the road to recovery.
The west London club are yet to lose a game under the Dutchman and earned an FA Cup fourth round spot on Sunday after beating Scunthorpe United 2-0 at Stamford Bridge.
